title: 112_hr2873
content: The Act titled "Small Business Expansion and Hiring Act of 2011" introduces a new section in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, providing a business credit for retaining certain individuals hired before 2013. The Small Business Expansion and Hiring Act of 2011 introduces a new tax credit for retaining workers hired before 2013. The credit is based on a percentage of wages paid to retained workers, with limitations on the number of employees eligible for the credit. The tax credit for retaining workers under the Small Business Expansion and Hiring Act of 2011 is limited to $400,000 per business location. Determinations of employee numbers are location-specific, and employees moved between locations are not eligible for the credit. A retained worker is defined as a qualified individual. The Small Business Expansion and Hiring Act of 2011 offers a tax credit for retaining qualified individuals employed by the taxpayer for at least 52 consecutive weeks, with specific wage criteria. Qualified individuals are those who start employment with a qualified employer between 2010 and 2014 and provide a signed affidavit confirming their eligibility. The Small Business Expansion and Hiring Act of 2011 provides a tax credit for retaining qualified individuals employed by a qualified employer for at least 52 consecutive weeks. Qualified individuals must not have worked 40 hours or more per week in the 60-day period before starting employment, must not be replacing another employee unless that employee left voluntarily or for cause, and must not be an individual described in section 51(i)(1). The Small Business Expansion and Hiring Act of 2011 offers a tax credit for retaining qualified individuals employed by a qualified employer for 52 consecutive weeks. A qualified employer includes those with less than 100 employees or public higher education institutions. A long-term unemployed individual is defined as someone who received unemployment compensation for at least 26 weeks before being hired. The Small Business Expansion and Hiring Act of 2011 provides a tax credit for retaining qualified individuals employed by a qualified employer for 52 consecutive weeks. The tax credit is determined under section 45S of the Internal Revenue Code, with a 3-year carryforward limitation for the retained worker credit. Additionally, a clerical amendment was made to the table of sections for subpart D of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The amendments made by section 45S apply to taxable years after the enactment of the Act.
